paragraphs.content: **Reflexive pronouns** correspond to ‘myself’, ‘yourself’, etc. in phrases like ‘you flatter yourself’, ‘the cat’s licking itself’, ‘the recorder’s switched itself off’. In such cases, the **subject** and the **object** of the verb are the same person or thing:

rows: You always look at yourself in the mirror.
I get washed. [lit. I wash myself]
Anna’s getting dressed for the party. [lit. Anna’s dressing herself]

paragraphs.content: These examples show how the **reflexive pronouns** are the **direct objects** of the verbs **lavare**, **guardare**, and **vestire** and denote the same person as the **subject**.
There are very many verbs which can be used in the **reflexive form** in Italian and which do not correspond to English reflexive verbs. Here is a list of some of the most common ones:

rows: to fall asleep [lit. to send oneself to sleep]
to get up [lit. to raise oneself]
to get/be bored [lit. to bore oneself]
to get washed [lit. to wash oneself]
to take offence [lit. to offend oneself]
to be wrong/mistaken [lit. to mistake oneself]
to sit down [lit. to seat oneself]
to feel (well, ill, etc.) [lit. to feel oneself]
to wake up [lit. to waken oneself]
to get dressed [lit. to dress oneself]

paragraphs.content: The forms of the **reflexive pronouns** are as follows:
* Note that the third person singular and plural pronoun **si** is the same.
Examples with **incontrarsi** (to meet each other, reciprocal):
In **compound tenses** like the **present perfect**, reflexive verbs always take the auxiliary **essere**, and the **past participle** agrees in **gender** and **number** with the subject:

rows: Vittorio, a che ora **ti sei alzato**?
Vittorio, what time did you get up?
Paolo and Francesca have got married.
Claudio e Anna **si sono lavati** le mani.
Claudio and Anna washed their hands.

paragraphs.content: The **reflexive pronouns**, like all **unstressed pronouns**, can be **attached** to the **infinitive** of a verb (mainly after **dovere**, **potere**, **volere**, or **sapere**). In these sentences, when the main verb is in the **present perfect** (or any other compound tense), the **auxiliary** is **avere**, and the **past participle** does **not agree**:

rows: I’ve got to get up early.
My brother doesn’t want to wash.
Paolo and Francesca wanted to get married.

paragraphs.content: However, when the **reflexive pronoun** is **not attached** to the infinitive, the **auxiliary verb** must be **essere**, and the **past participle** does **agree**:

rows: I had to get up early.
Paolo e Francesca **si sono voluti** sposare.
Paolo and Francesca wanted to get married.

paragraphs.content: The **reflexive pronouns** also have **stressed forms** which are used, like the stressed forms of other pronouns, for **emphasis** and after a **preposition**. These forms are often reinforced by the adjective **stesso**:
* Note that **sé** does not have an accent when it is used with **stesso**.

rows: Look at yourself in the mirror!

exercises.title: Exercise 1: Insert Reflexive/Reciprocal Pronouns
exercises.instruction: Insert the correct **reflexive** or **reciprocal pronoun** in the blank spaces.

items.question: Nina non **—** veste mai di rosso.
items.answer: Nina non si veste mai di rosso.

items.question: Carlo e Luca non **—** conoscono.
items.answer: Carlo e Luca non si conoscono.

exercises.title: Exercise 2: Insert Reflexive/Reciprocal Pronouns
exercises.instruction: Insert the correct **reflexive** or **reciprocal pronoun** in the blank spaces (past context).
examples: Ieri **—** sono alzati presto.: Ieri **si** sono alzati presto.
Anna **—** è lavata prima di uscire.: Anna **si** è lavata prima di uscire.

items.question: Anna **—** è lavata prima di uscire.
items.answer: Anna si è lavata prima di uscire.

items.question: Loro **—** sono sposati l’anno scorso.
items.answer: Loro si sono sposati l’anno scorso.

items.question: Non **—** sei divertito alla festa?
items.answer: Non ti sei divertito alla festa?

items.question: Noi **—** siamo incontrati al parco.
items.answer: Noi ci siamo incontrati al parco.

items.question: Carlo **—** è vestito di nero ieri.
items.answer: Carlo si è vestito di nero ieri.

items.question: Voi **—** siete riposati dopo il viaggio?
items.answer: Voi vi siete riposati dopo il viaggio?

items.question: Marina e Luca **—** sono scritti una lettera.
items.answer: Marina e Luca si sono scritti una lettera.

items.question: Non **—** si è annoiata durante il film.
items.answer: Non si è annoiata durante il film.

items.question: Loro **—** sono conosciuti al concerto.
items.answer: Loro si sono conosciuti al concerto.

exercises.title: Exercise 3: Present Perfect of Reflexive Verbs
exercises.instruction: Put the verbs into the **present perfect** tense.

items.question: Noi (**alzarci**) presto oggi.
items.answer: Noi ci siamo alzati presto oggi.

items.question: Tu [m] (**lavarti**) le mani?
items.answer: Tu ti sei lavato le mani?

items.question: Loro (**sposarsi**) l’anno scorso.
items.answer: Loro si sono sposati l’anno scorso.

items.question: Voi (**divertirvi**) alla festa?
items.answer: Voi vi siete divertiti alla festa?

items.question: Marina (**guardarsi**) allo specchio.
items.answer: Marina si è guardata allo specchio.

items.question: Carlo e Luca (**incontrarsi**) ieri.
items.answer: Carlo e Luca si sono incontrati ieri.

items.question: Silvano (**annoarsi**) durante la lezione.
items.answer: Silvano si è annoiato durante la lezione.
